SearchResults.name: Calculator
SearchResults.description:
A simple javascript calculator, which has a few memory functions for convenience.
 This calculator does not use the eval function as many javascript calculator do.
 Instead it maintains a simple mathematical state machine using base 10 calculations to append and remove digits from the number.

SearchResults.name: Activity_Timer_Candle
SearchResults.description: Activity Timer Candle is a useful widget for short focussed timed activities. The widget is easily editable by the teacher for different tasks. It could be used to time students giving feedback in the REFLECT activity, to time presentations in the SHOW activity, or for students to brainstorm ideas to make sense of the design brief in the DREAM activity.

SearchResults.name: Random_Story_Starters

SearchResults.name: Activity_Group_Spinner

SearchResults.name: Activity_Timer_Hour_Glass

SearchResults.name: Activity_Traffic_Light

This learning story is inspired by the abstract iTEC scenario "Beam in the expert".
In a nutshell, this learning story tries to teach object oriented programming by integrating an external domain expert.

SearchResults.name: Cycle 4 - Tell a story - Ein Bericht über die Verwendung von Solarautos
SearchResults.description: Warum sind Solarautos in der EU und auf der ganzen Welt von Bedeutung? In manchen europäischen Ländern erregen Solarautorennen Aufmerksamkeit. Gruppen von Studenten und Erwachsenen entwerfen und bauen ihre eigenen Autos, mit denen sie an diesen Wettbewerben teilnehmen. Außerdem investieren große Automobilunternehmen Geld und Forschung in die solargetriebenen Autos der Zukunft.

SearchResults.name: Activity Registration (391058)
SearchResults.description: Der Bernoulli Effekt wird anhand eines Experimentes aus dem NTL Aerodynamik Koffers vorgeführt. In Peergroups (SchülerInnen der 8. Schulstufe und SchülerInnen der 6. Schulstufe) werden an 4 Stationentischen Kleinexperimente mit Bezug zum Hauptexperiment durchgeführt. Dabei wird die Methode des Forschenden Lernens angewandt.

SearchResults.name: Visualizing the planet surface - Our city guide
SearchResults.description: French primary pupils create an online city guide, enhancing the highlight places of their town (wine producing castles, cooking school and training restaurant, traditional French bakery...)

SearchResults.name: Forming Teams
SearchResults.description: Divide the students in your class into teams of 4-5 students. Each team works on a separate topic of inquiry that is related to the theme of the course. The students suggest topics they are interested in and are grouped accordingly, taking also into account their differences to create functional heterogeneous teams.

SearchResults.name: Contextual Inquiry: Benchmarking
SearchResults.description: Student teams collect 10 examples of the kind of artifact that is similar to the one they are trying to design.

SearchResults.name: Final Product Design2
SearchResults.description: Based on Design Brief 4 and the analysis of the Participatory Design Workshop, the student teams create their final design prototype. The teams listen to all of their reflection recordings once more to update the challenges they encountered during each design activity workshop and to reflect on the strategies they used to overcome these challenges. The students finalize their documentation blog, and may present their final works to the entire class. Classroom time needed: 1-2 lesson(s)

SearchResults.name: Working with a Wiki and a Chat
Show: Final Report of the Prototype Solarcar
ITEC_OGUZCAN
SearchResults.description: A brief description of the ITEC project in Turkey

SearchResults.name: Participatory Design Workshop
SearchResults.description: The students teams meet with 3 - 4 people, whom they consider to be the future users of their design and perform a Participatory Design Workshop. The students use their prototype and Design Brief 3 to communicate their design ideas to a group of people they are designing for. This may involve prints of their prototype, drawings or models, pens and post-it notes that the participants can use to draw on and modify the prototype. After the workshop the students analyze the comments of the people and decide which ones to consider for their design. They then refine their design brief, especially in relation to the design challenges, context and added value of the result, record a reflection and update their blog. Classroom time needed: 1-2 lesson(s)

SearchResults.name: Show: Final Report alternative lightbulbs
SearchResults.description: Presentation of the Results about alternative Lightbulbs compared to standard Bulbs. Show Advantages and Disadvantages (Peter Stöckelmaier, Austria)

SearchResults.name: Working with outside experts
SearchResults.description: Students receive additional and/or deeper knowledge from an out-of-school expert of a relevant field. In addition to a video interview, the expert may be involved in following teamwork and commenting on it.

SearchResults.name: Hardy Weinburg equilibria
SearchResults.description: work through the equation using the link

SearchResults.name: Ask
SearchResults.description: Teams meet with 2–4 people, who could be future users of the prototypes, and communicate their prototypes and design ideas using prints, drawings or models.

SearchResults.name: Map
SearchResults.description: Teams analyse their findings using mind-mapping techniques. They identify relations, similarities and differences between the examples and/or media files they collected.

SearchResults.name: Interview (immigrants)
SearchResults.description: Collect data from people with different cultural backgrounds, and different proficiency of language.

SearchResults.name: iTEC Teachers Contextual Inquiry: Benchmarking
SearchResults.description:
Based on their design brief, students identify what kind of examples of existing works to collect. Their choice depends on who they are designing for, what they are designing and the initial challenges they want to address. Student teams collect 10 examples of the kind of artifact that is similar to the one they are trying to design. They share their collected media files and analyze the differences and similarities of the example works they collected. Based on their collected information and analysis, the students refine their design brief, especially the design challenges and design results. They then record a reflection and update their blog. Classroom time needed: 1-2 lesson(s)

TERMINOLOGY – An inquiry is an act of asking for information. Benchmarking is indicated to be the way. In our design activities, the word contextual refers to the circumstances that the students would like to design for or place their design into. So, here, the students use benchmarking to collect information about the situation and factors of their design and that may inform their design.

SearchResults.name: Learning Oriented Browsing
SearchResults.description: Developing 21st century skills includes building the ability to use the internet in a focused way to find relevant information from meaningful sources. In this activity, the students use the internet in a structured way to collect information about a specific topic, and to locate online learning resources that they can be critically used in their inquiry. Recommended frequency: at least two times

SearchResults.name: Reflection
SearchResults.description: The students record, post and share periodic audio updates about their project progression, perceived challenges, changes to the design brief and future plans. The students slowly build a database of learning strategies that is shared with the entire class. The audio recordings and the design brief can be used as a media to prompt reflection, and objects that should be more closely refined after each reflection. Classroom time: at least 15 minutes after each design phase

SearchResults.name: Final Product Design
SearchResults.description: Based on Design Brief 4 and the analysis of the Participatory Design Workshop, the student teams create their final design prototype. The teams listen to all of their reflection recordings once more to update the challenges they encountered during each design activity workshop and to reflect on the strategies they used to overcome these challenges. The students finalize their documentation blog, and may present their final works to the entire class. Classroom time needed: 1-2 lesson(s)

SearchResults.name: Participatory Design Workshop
SearchResults.description: The students teams meet with 3 - 4 people, whom they consider to be the future users of their design and perform a Participatory Design Workshop. The students use their prototype and Design Brief 3 to communicate their design ideas to a group of people they are designing for. This may involve prints of their prototype, drawings or models, pens and post-it notes that the participants can use to draw on and modify the prototype. After the workshop the students analyze the comments of the people and decide which ones to consider for their design. They then refine their design brief, especially in relation to the design challenges, context and added value of the result, record a reflection and update their blog. Classroom time needed: 1-2 lesson(s)

SearchResults.name: Product Design
SearchResults.description: Based on their Design Brief 2 and their initial design ideas, students create their first prototype design. The students discuss their prototype and refine their design brief, especially in relation to the design result and the way the result addresses the identified design challenges. They then record a reflection and update their blog. Classroom time needed: 1-2 lesson(s)

SearchResults.name: Contextual Inquiry: Benchmarking
SearchResults.description: Based on their design brief, students identify what kind of examples of existing works to collect. Their choice depends on who they are designing for, what they are designing and the initial challenges they want to address. Student teams collect 10 examples of the kind of artifact that is similar to the one they are trying to design. They share their collected media files and analyze the differences and similarities of the example works they collected. Based on their collected information and analysis, the students refine their design brief, especially the design challenges and design results. They then record a reflection and update their blog. Classroom time needed: 1-2 lesson(s)

SearchResults.name: Contextual Inquiry - Observation
SearchResults.description: Based on their design brief, students identify who and what to observe to inform their design result, for example practices or environments of particular people or animals. Their choice depends on who they are designing for, what they are designing and the initial challenges they want to address. Student teams perform their planned observation by using digital cameras, notebooks and microphones to document what they see. They share their collected media files and analyze them. Based on their collected information and analysis, the students refine their design brief, especially the design challenges and design results. They then record a reflection and update their blog. Classroom time needed: 1-3 lesson(s)

SearchResults.name: Design brief
SearchResults.description: You present an initial design brief to the students that ties the design tasks to the curriculum topics, but leaves some aspects open for refinement. During this lesson, you also provide the students with the motivation for and explain the responsibility they will carry for being involved. Students form teams, discuss, question and familiarize themselves with the brief. They refine their design brief context, particularly in relation of who/what they are designing for, initial design challenges and possible design results. Students record a reflection, set up a blog for their documentation, and start their documentation. Classroom time needed: 1 lesson

 the while, she's breathing in and out, and watch the tail. She may even try to swat the cursor. The creator of this entertaining feline is unknown.
